summary: Replace harsh blinking caret with smooth breathing animation to aid focus
problem_statement: The default browser caret blinks with a hard on/off flash—a small but persistent source of visual tension. For writers spending sustained time in the editor, the harsh blink is a micro-distraction that accumulates. A smooth, breathing caret (gradual fade in/out) is perceptually calmer, signals that the environment is alive without demanding attention, and reinforces the sensory calm established by the accent colour and breathing space work. This is a small surface-area change with outsized impact on perceived polish and focus.
in_scope: Override or replace the default browser caret with a custom animated caret
Implement a smooth breathing animation (fade or opacity pulse) instead of hard blink
Ensure caret colour inherits the single accent or a harmonious neutral
Caret animation respects prefers-reduced-motion media query
Caret remains visible and functional during typing, selection, and navigation
out_of_scope: Word count, milestones, or feedback overlays (P3)
Rich text or cursor-based collaborative features
requirements: Caret uses a smooth fade/pulse animation instead of hard on/off blink
Animation cycle is ≥800ms to feel calm (not frantic)
Caret respects prefers-reduced-motion: falls back to static or native blink
Caret is visible on all background colours used in the Write view
No measurable impact on input latency or typing performance
acceptance_criteria: Caret animates with a smooth breathing rhythm (no hard on/off)
With prefers-reduced-motion enabled, caret falls back gracefully
Caret contrast is sufficient against editor background (≥3:1)
Typing, arrow-key navigation, and text selection work without visual glitch
No regression in input latency benchmarks
dependencies: P1-uix-01 (Full-width editor layout) — caret renders within the expanded viewport
P2-uix-04 (Single accent colour) — caret colour may derive from accent palette
P2-uix-05 (Breathing space) — spacing context affects caret visual weight
risks: Custom caret may not be supported in all browsers or input modes (IME, mobile keyboards)
Overriding native caret can break accessibility tooling or screen magnifiers
Animation that is too slow may feel laggy; too fast undermines the calm intent
implementation_notes: P2-uix-06 closes Phase 2 (Sensory). Approach: use CSS caret-color plus a custom overlay element, or leverage the contenteditable caret if the editor supports it. For textarea-based editors, a thin absolutely-positioned div synced to cursor position may be needed—measure perf impact carefully. Animation: CSS @keyframes with opacity (e.g. 1 → 0.2 → 1 over ~1200ms ease-in-out). Always gate behind prefers-reduced-motion. Reference epic DoD: platform feels still, not busy.
